title: 113_s1135
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fracturing Responsibility and Awareness of Chemicals Act" or the "FRAC Act." It regulates hydraulic fracturing. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to include the definition of underground injection, which encompasses the injection of fluids or propping agents for hydraulic fracturing in oil or gas production, excluding natural gas storage. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow states to seek primary enforcement responsibility for hydraulic fracturing operations for oil and natural gas, separate from other types of underground injection control wells. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow states to seek primary enforcement responsibility for hydraulic fracturing operations for oil and natural gas, separate from other types of underground injection control wells. Additionally, regulations for tertiary recovery of oil or natural gas are delayed until one year after publication in the Federal Register. Disclosure requirements for chemical constituents in hydraulic fracturing are also added. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow states or the Administrator to require disclosure of chemicals and proppants used in hydraulic fracturing operations before commencement. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow states or the Administrator to require disclosure of chemicals and proppants used in hydraulic fracturing operations before commencement, as well as after completion, including details such as chemical constituents, Chemical Abstracts Service numbers, and material safety data sheets. The Safe Drinking Water Act amendment allows for the disclosure of chemicals and proppants used in hydraulic fracturing operations. The information must be accurate, complete, and made publicly available on a searchable website. Immediate disclosure is required in case of medical need or emergency. The regulations require immediate disclosure of trade-secret chemical formulas in hydraulic fracturing for medical diagnosis, treatment, or emergency response. The regulations mandate disclosure of trade-secret chemical formulas in hydraulic fracturing for medical diagnosis, treatment, or emergency response, regardless of the need for a written statement or confidentiality agreement. A first responder or healthcare practitioner may share medically necessary information disclosed under a clause with others, but they are restricted from making it publicly available. No public disclosure required for proprietary chemical formula under clause (i).
